instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has image on external monitor, but no image on internal LCD.
The LCD connector was a little burnt, and so i changed, but without success.

Tried with known good lcd, without success.

I have 5V on pins 28 ~ 30 of J8300
F7700 = 12.59V

I have on <CHIP>U5450</CHIP>:
PIN 3 = 8.8V
PIN 4,5 and 6 = 12,59V

<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 8.8V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
"I have on <CHIP>U5450</CHIP>:
PIN 3 = 8.8V"
I hope not; pay atention to schematic.

Post diode mode to ground at both pins of <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>; w/ and w/o LCD connected.

"<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 8.8V"
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> level?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
I didn't realize that PIN 3 of <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> was PP3V3, but the measure is correct. It has 8.8V (measured with two different multimeters).

Diode readings <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> :
With LCD =
PIN 1 =1.2V
PIN 2 = 0.9V

Without LCD =
PIN 1 = 1.2V
PIN 2 = 0.9V

<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 8.8V (<RESISTOR>R7702</RESISTOR>)
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL>  = 5.9V (<RESISTOR>R7702</RESISTOR>)

<RESISTOR>R7702</RESISTOR> = 63.3 K ohm

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Very strange values.

Do you really have 8.8V at <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>???
Check at <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Sorry..
I'm a dumm. I was measuring at the wrong component...
I don't have the <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> on my board. I confused it with the <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Sorry..
I'm a dumm. I was measuring at the wrong component...
I don't have the <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> on my board. I confused it with the <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>

On <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> I have:
PIN 1 = 12.59V
PIN 2 = 12.59v
PIN 3 =  8.8v
PIN 4 = 12.59V
PIN 5 = 12.59V
PIN 6 = 12.59V

<SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>  is 3.3V

On <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> I have:
PIN 17 = 5.1V
PIN 2 = 5.1V
PIN 21 = 44V
PIN 15 = 5.1V
PIN 16 = 5.1 V
PIN 8 = 5.1V

<DIODE>D7710</DIODE>:
PIN 1= 49V
PIN2 = 8.3V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
"<DIODE>D7710</DIODE>:
PIN 1= 49V"
Backlight driver is OK; there is no connection with LEDs strip.
You have a problem with LCD connector, video cable, or display (most likely).
Correct voltage is 40V aprox; when LEDs strip is properly connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
I've tried 2 LCD's. 
I've replaced the J8300, because mac had no image, and J8300 was a bit burnt on pins 28-30. With other J8300, and with other LCD, it still has no image. I'm testing it with the board alone, and a known good LCD, but still no image.
Can it be a bad solder J8300?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Bad solders, or bad contacts inisde connector.
Do you still have 49V after all changes?
Clean with IPA when you insert the video cable.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi,
Sorry for the long time to answer.
I've replaced once again the J8300 connector and I still have no image, and 49V on <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>. All the solders are OK, and  J8300 well cleaned with IPA.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Then bad video cable, or display...
Just in case, check backlight voltage on a good machine.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi,
In a working <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, the BL voltage is 48.8V. However, it seams that when I twist the cable, it shows a dim image, I'll try with other LCD.
